articles.headline: Start-Up Spirit Emerges in Japan
articles.snippet: While prejudice against entrepreneurs lingers in Japan, the nation is increasingly trying to encourage business start-ups as a key to the future.
articles.abstract: While prejudice against entrepreneurs lingers in Japan, the nation is increasingly trying to encourage business start-ups as a key to the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The 20-somethings in jeans sipping espresso and tapping on laptops at this Tokyo business incubator would look more at home in Silicon Valley than in Japan, where for years the surest signs of success were the gray suits of its corporate salarymen. But for those hoping the nation’s latest economic plan will drag Japan from its long malaise, the young men and women here at Samurai Startup Island represent a crucial component: a revival of entrepreneurship.

articles.headline: Scotland Fights to Keep Energy Lifeline
articles.snippet: The petrochemical complex at Grangemouth has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.
articles.abstract: The petrochemical complex at Grangemouth has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANGEMOUTH, Scotland — The vast petrochemical complex at Grangemouth is a constellation of lights and glowing plumes of steam west of Edinburgh that has become a shimmering symbol of Scotland at an economic and political crossroads.

articles.headline: Islamic Banks, Stuffed With Cash, Explore Partnerships in West
articles.snippet: Middle Eastern banks, in search of diversified investment opportunities, are seeking companies abroad that can do business in ways compliant with Islamic law.
articles.abstract: Middle Eastern banks, in search of diversified investment opportunities, are seeking companies abroad that can do business in ways compliant with Islamic law.
articles.lead_paragraph: A noted Muslim law scholar, Yusuf DeLorenzo, recently pored through the books of Continental Rail, a business that runs freight trains up and down the East Coast.

articles.headline: Wind Power Developers Race Clock to Secure Subsidy
articles.snippet: To claim a valuable tax credit for the first 10 years of power production, those in the industry must meet certain project guidelines by year-end.
articles.abstract: To claim a valuable tax credit for the first 10 years of power production, those in the industry must meet certain project guidelines by year-end.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the rest of the world prepares to toast the new year, the wind industry is hard at work on its own year-end tradition, rushing to make sure projects qualify for an important subsidy before it is set to vanish at the stroke of midnight on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Gifts Sent by U.P.S. Miss a Big Deadline
articles.snippet: Some customers were left without Christmas gifts as the United Parcel Service failed to meet delivery deadlines in the face of bad weather and an unexpectedly large surge in demand.
articles.abstract: Some customers were left without Christmas gifts as the United Parcel Service failed to meet delivery deadlines in the face of bad weather and an unexpectedly large surge in demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Santa delivered sacks stuffed with i.o.u.’s this Christmas.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and David Gelles

articles.headline: In a Car-Culture Clash, It’s the Los Angeles Police vs. Pedestrians
articles.snippet: A crackdown on jaywalkers has raised questions about whether the police are siding with the automobile at a time when the city’s pedestrian culture is taking off.
articles.abstract: A crackdown on jaywalkers has raised questions about whether the police are siding with the automobile at a time when the city’s pedestrian culture is taking off.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a city of seemingly endless highways — with its daily parade of car accidents, frustrating traffic jams and aggressive drivers — the Los Angeles Police Department these days is training its sights on a different road menace: jaywalkers.

articles.headline: E.R. Costs for Mentally Ill Soar, and Hospitals Seek Better Way
articles.snippet: The cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill shows no sign of ebbing, but a North Carolina hospital is experimenting to save money and better help patients.
articles.abstract: The cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill shows no sign of ebbing, but a North Carolina hospital is experimenting to save money and better help patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — As darkness fell on a Friday evening over downtown Raleigh, N.C., Michael Lyons, a paramedic supervisor for Wake County Emergency Medical Services, slowly approached the tall, lanky man who was swaying back and forth in a gentle rhythm.

articles.headline: U.S. Sends Arms to Aid Iraq Fight With Extremists
articles.snippet: After an appeal for help, the United States is rushing dozens of missiles and surveillance drones to help Iraqi forces combat violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency.
articles.abstract: After an appeal for help, the United States is rushing dozens of missiles and surveillance drones to help Iraqi forces combat violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is quietly rushing dozens of Hellfire missiles and low-tech surveillance drones to Iraq to help government forces combat an explosion of violence by a Qaeda-backed insurgency that is gaining territory in both western Iraq and neighboring Syria.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Egypt Broadens New Crackdown on Brotherhood
articles.snippet: With dozens of arrests and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles, Egypt’s new rulers signaled that they had opened a wide-ranging war on every facet of the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities.
articles.abstract: With dozens of arrests and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles, Egypt’s new rulers signaled that they had opened a wide-ranging war on every facet of the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Just a day after Egypt’s military-backed government declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist group, a more aggressive crackdown was already emerging Thursday, as the authorities announced dozens of arrests across the country, and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles belonging to the Islamist movement’s members.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and Mayy El Sheikh
